On 8/3/06, Robert Martin <UncleBob@...> wrote:
>
> > Hehe... I=
f I'm a heretic because I recommend using your common sense
> > instead of =
one-liners such as "always test first", then yes, guilty as
> > charged :-)=

>
> I have grown intolerant of the attitude that testing is optional.


I =
never said testing was optional.

I don't know about you, but what makes my=
 job fascinating is that it's a
constant mix of tasks with sometimes confli=
cting objectives:

   - Designing
   - Working with product managers
   - C=
oding
   - Debugging
   - Testing
   - Working with tech writers
   - Shipp=
ing
   - Supporting

I am paid to make decisions in all these areas and pri=
oritize them, and in
order to ship good software, you need to score very we=
ll on all of these
counts.

The respective priorities of these tasks change=
 depending on which cycle in
your software development you are, and while t=
esting is a high priority task
in my mind at all times, it's obvious that a=
t some point, it needs to be
preempted by more urgent tasks.

What makes so=
meone a good professional is knowing when such a situation
arises.

What ma=
kes someone a bad professional is when they put a task at the top of
their =
priority regardless of the context.

-- 
C=E9dric
